comments.comment:
I tried making this apam balik today and things went sideways pretty quickly. The batter looked fine at first, but once I poured it into the pan it just refused to form those nice little bubbles—it stayed flat and kind of gummy. I think I might have overmixed it because the texture turned out way denser than it should be. Then, when I tried spreading the batter up the sides of the pan, it kept sliding back down, so the edges never crisped up.

To make matters worse, the bottom started browning way too fast while the top was still pale and sticky, so when I added the butter, corn, peanuts, and sugar, everything just sank straight into the mush instead of sitting nicely on top. When I tried folding it, it tore right in the middle and half the filling leaked onto the pan and burned. I still ate a piece out of stubbornness, but it definitely did NOT resemble apam balik in any universe. I’ll have to give it another try, maybe lower the heat and double-check my flour measurements next time!

I followed this recipe exactly as written, and I have to say I am seriously disappointed. I don’t usually leave comments, but this experience was so frustrating I feel like I need to warn other people. Everything seemed straightforward on paper, but the instructions were way too vague, and I’m convinced that’s why my entire batch turned into a disaster.

First of all, the batter consistency was completely off. The recipe just says to “stir well until all ingredients are combined evenly,” but doesn’t mention what the texture should look like or how long to mix. I ended up with something that seemed too thick, but since there was no guidance, I figured it was fine. Spoiler: it was NOT fine. The batter cooked up like a stodgy brick instead of a soft pancake.

Then the step that says to “spread a thin layer of batter to the side of the pan” gave me zero clue how thin, how high, or how much batter to use. I tried to improvise, and everything slid back down, burned on one side, and stayed raw on the other. The instructions also completely ignored heat levels—low? medium? high? I had to guess, and judging by the smoky chaos in my kitchen, I guessed very, very wrong.

When it came time to add the butter, corn, peanuts, and sugar, everything melted into a sticky puddle that caramelized in the worst possible way. It glued itself to the pan, and when I tried to fold the pancake, it basically snapped in half and left a crusty, sugary mess that took me 20 minutes to scrape off. By the end, I was standing there with a pan full of ruined batter, a smoky kitchen, and zero edible apam balik to show for it.

Honestly, I’m not even sure if the problem was me or the recipe, but the instructions were so unhelpful that I’m blaming them. I followed every step, and it still fell apart at every stage. I’m officially done. I will never make this recipe again.
this recipe was amazing so yummy this is the best thing i have ever made. seriously delicious
Best thing i have ever tasted!

This veggie stir-fry recipe impressed me with its balance of flavor, texture, and simplicity. The instructions were concise, and the ingredients were easy to find, making it a perfect last-minute meal. The highlight of the recipe was definitely the sauce: a combination of soy sauce, garlic, ginger, and a touch of sweetness that blended beautifully. It coated the vegetables without feeling heavy or overly salty. The cooking method preserved the veggies’ crunch, resulting in a dish that felt both fresh and satisfying. I appreciated the flexibility of the recipe—almost any vegetable works well here. I used bell peppers, broccoli, snap peas, and mushrooms, and each one absorbed the flavors while maintaining its distinct taste. Adding tofu or chicken would turn this into a complete meal, but even without protein it was filling and wholesome. The entire dish came together in under 20 minutes, making it ideal for busy evenings. I served it over jasmine rice, which complemented the savory sauce perfectly. Leftovers reheated wonderfully, maintaining both flavor and texture. For anyone searching for a quick, healthy, and flavorful dinner option, this stir-fry is a fantastic choice. It’s fresh, colorful, and consistently delicious.
These became crispy instead of fluffy.
This tasted really good, and was easy to make!
Perhaps rewrite the instructions? Otherwise, special recepite

This hearty vegetable soup exceeded my expectations in both flavor and ease of preparation. The recipe offered a wonderful base that was versatile enough to accommodate whatever vegetables I had available. I loved how the process started with sautéing onions, carrots, and celery, creating a deep, aromatic foundation. The broth absorbed the flavors beautifully as the soup simmered, and the addition of herbs like thyme and bay leaf made each spoonful fragrant and comforting. What impressed me most was how vibrant the vegetables remained; they softened perfectly without turning mushy. The soup felt nourishing and wholesome, almost like something homemade from childhood memories. I added a bit of lemon juice before serving, which brightened the flavors and balanced the heartiness. One notable advantage is that the soup tastes even better the next day after the flavors have fully melded. It also freezes exceptionally well, making it ideal for meal prepping. Whether enjoyed on a chilly evening or as a light lunch with crusty bread, this recipe delivers warmth and satisfaction in every bowl. It’s a perfect choice for anyone wanting a healthy, flavorful meal that feels both rustic and soothing. I’ll definitely be making it again.

Loved this pasta! The sauce was creamy, balanced, and surprisingly simple. Definitely adding it to my weeknight rotation.

This creamy garlic pasta recipe turned out far better than I expected. The instructions were simple to follow, and the ingredient list was refreshingly short, making it ideal for a quick dinner. The sauce came together beautifully—silky, rich, and full of deep garlic flavor without being overwhelming. I appreciated that the recipe encouraged slowly sautéing the garlic to bring out sweetness rather than bitterness. The balance of cream, Parmesan, and pasta water created a texture that clung perfectly to every noodle. I added a small handful of fresh parsley and a squeeze of lemon, which made the dish feel even brighter. What I loved most was how customizable it is; you can add spinach, chicken, mushrooms, or even sun-dried tomatoes without compromising the base flavor. It's also incredibly comforting, the kind of dish that tastes like something you’d order at a cozy Italian restaurant. Reheating leftovers was surprisingly successful—the sauce didn’t split or turn grainy like many cream-based dishes sometimes do. This recipe has officially become one of my go-to weeknight dinners because it strikes that rare balance of tasting indulgent while being extremely easy. Highly recommended for pasta lovers

These chocolate chip cookies were absolutely delightful—soft, chewy, and full of rich flavor. The recipe was straightforward, and the results tasted like something from a bakery but made right at home. I especially appreciated the use of melted butter, which gave the cookies a deep caramel-like undertone. Allowing the dough to rest, even just briefly, made a noticeable difference in texture. The cookies baked up with crisp edges and gooey centers, the perfect combination for cookie lovers. I used a mix of dark and semi-sweet chocolate chips, and the contrast added a wonderful depth of flavor. The recommended baking time was spot-on; they stayed soft long after cooling, which is always a challenge with homemade cookies. I also liked that the recipe wasn’t overly sweet, letting the chocolate truly shine. These cookies stayed fresh and chewy for several days, making them great for sharing or packing in lunches. They are incredibly customizable—nuts, sea salt, or espresso powder would be great additions. Overall, this recipe is a keeper and will become my standard chocolate chip cookie recipe. It’s easy, reliable, and produces consistently delicious results that satisfy any craving for a classic treat

This classic comfort casserole delivered everything I hoped for—warmth, heartiness, and satisfaction. The recipe was incredibly easy to follow, even for beginners. It layered familiar ingredients like pasta, cheese, vegetables, and a creamy sauce into a rich, cohesive dish. Each layer contributed something special, and the flavors blended beautifully during baking. I particularly loved the golden, bubbly cheese on top, which added a perfectly crisp contrast to the creamy layers beneath. The casserole held its shape well when sliced, making it great for serving guests or bringing to gatherings. One of the best features of the recipe is its adaptability; you can substitute different vegetables, add protein like chicken or ground beef, or experiment with various cheeses. It reheated wonderfully and even seemed more flavorful the next day. This dish delivers pure comfort and nostalgia, reminiscent of family dinners and cozy evenings. It’s the kind of recipe that becomes a dependable favorite—simple, filling, and crowd-pleasing. Whether you’re cooking for picky eaters or a large group, this casserole is a reliable choice that consistently hits the spot. I’ll definitely be returning to this recipe anytime I need an easy, comforting meal.

This warm spiced curry recipe was absolutely delicious and surprisingly easy to make. The depth of flavor came from layering spices like cumin, turmeric, coriander, and garam masala, creating a fragrant and comforting dish. The aroma alone made the cooking process enjoyable. I appreciated how the recipe encouraged toasting the spices before adding liquids; this step enhanced the flavor significantly. The sauce was rich and velvety, coating every ingredient beautifully. I used chickpeas and vegetables, but the recipe is flexible enough to accommodate chicken, tofu, or lentils. The addition of coconut milk provided a creamy balance to the spices without making the dish feel heavy. The final squeeze of lime brightened everything and tied the flavors together. Served with warm rice or naan, this curry felt like a restaurant-quality meal made right in my kitchen. It also reheated exceptionally well, making it great for leftovers. Anyone who loves bold, warm flavors without too much effort will adore this recipe.

This fresh garden salad was elevated beautifully by the homemade dressing featured in the recipe. The base salad was simple—crisp lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, and carrots—but the dressing made it something special. The combination of olive oil, vinegar, herbs, and a touch of sweetness created a bright, lively flavor that tasted far better than store-bought options. I loved how quick the dressing was to prepare; just a few ingredients whisked together produced something wonderfully fresh. The instructions suggested letting the dressing sit for a few minutes to allow the flavors to meld, and this made a noticeable difference. The salad felt refreshing, light, and surprisingly satisfying, especially when topped with grilled chicken or chickpeas. This recipe reminded me how transformative a good dressing can be. It also keeps well in the refrigerator, so I ended up using it on multiple meals throughout the week. Overall, this salad and dressing combination is perfect for anyone wanting a healthy side dish that tastes vibrant and homemade.
